bibdata.title: Handle arks with no HTTP at all.
Change link from "My Library Card" to Library Account

comments.body:
If the use case is "As a cataloguer I want to know if my changes in Alma have indexed or are actively indexing" I don't think this is a good way to solve it. We don't tend to send people to bibdata, the dumps don't contain which BibIDs are attached to them, and if they had follow-ups we'd have to do a bunch more investigation anyways.

I wonder if we can wait until we get this request? If there's a question of "did my latest change get updated" then I think I'd want that indexed into Orangelight and displayed somewhere - maybe librarian view?
yes this makes a lot of sense. it's a pretty significant feature to write in anticipation of a question we haven't gotten yet.
yes this makes a lot of sense. it's a pretty significant feature to write in anticipation of a question we haven't gotten yet.

bibdata.title: Incremental index lock may fail if more than one incremental index job is queued

bibdata.title: Index all incremental dumps created since the most recent full dump

comments.body:
Here's a proposal for an IndexManager to coordinate indexing alma full and incremental dumps.

```
class IndexManager < ActiveRecord::Base
  solr_collection string
  dump_in_progress foreign key
  dumps_complete [foreign key]
  active boolean

  # returns the active IndexManager for the given collection
  def self.current(solr_collection)

  # finds and indexes the next incremental dump. no-op if there's a dump_in_progress.
  def next_incremental
```

Running a new full index on catalog-alma-rebuild:
  - Set current Index Manager for the rebuild collection to active:false
  - empty the rebuild index via the solr API
  - create a new IndexManager for the rebuild collection and set it to active
  - queue up the initial full dump
  - when a full dump finishes, it calls IndexManager.current(collection).next_incremental
    - the full dump index jobs will have to store a reference to the index manager or the collection they're going into for this to work.
    - sidekiq batches make an action like this possible via the batch callback

Ensuring all incrementals get indexed, and in the correct order
  - When a new incremental file gets transferred from sftp, call next_incremental on the configured primary `SOLR_COLLECTION`
  - When any incremental file finishes indexing, call next_incremental on the collection it indexed into
    - sidekiq batches make an action like this possible via the batch callback

Instead of configuring `SOLR_URL` and `SOLR_REINDEX_URL` in env, we configure `SOLR_BASE_URL`, `SOLR_COLLECTION`, and `SOLR_REINDEX_COLLECTION`.

Proposal:

See sidekiq batch example: https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq/wiki/Really-Complex-Workflows-with-Batches

Create a "super-batch" for each indexing operation.

When a Dump completes, look for any dumps after that dump and add it to the batch.

If another super-batch tries to enqueue, just fail out if one exists already.
Started playing with the batch implementation - a problem that happens is you need to keep track of which Dumps are indexed into which core to do start-stop indexing.
